Title:
Morphological and phylogenetic characterization of forestry
fungi within Hyphodermataceae: introducing two new species from the
southern China
Keywords:
Corticioid fungi; Diversity; Hyphodermataceae; Molecular
phylogeny; Taxonomy; Yunnan Province
Abstract:
Abstract: The wood-inhabiting fungi play crucial roles in
sustaining the functioning as decom-posers in the forest ecosystems, and
two new forest ecological fungi, Hyphoderma puerense and H. tenuissimum
spp. nov. are proposed based on a combination of morphological features
and molecular evidence. Hyphoderma puerense is characterized by effused,
basidiomata with smooth to flocculent hymenial surface, a monomitic
hyphal system with clamped generative hyphae and ellipsoid
basidiospores. Hyphoderma tenuissimum is characterized by resupinate
basidiomata with tuberculate to minutely-grandinioid hymenial surface,
presence of septate cystidia and cylindrical to allantoid basidiospores.
Sequences of ITS+nLSU rRNA gene regions of the studied samples were
generated, and phylogenetic analyses were performed with maximum
likelihood, maximum parsimony, and Bayesian inference methods. These
phylogenetic analyses showed that two new species clustered into
Hyphoderma, in which H. puerense grouped with H. moniliforme, and H.
tenuissimum was sister to H. mopanshanense. In addition to new species,
identification key to Chinese Hyphoderma are provided.
